['Check out our premium machine learning course with 2 Industry projects: https://codebasics.io/courses/machine-learning-for-data-science-beginners-to-advanced', 'Really liked your  videos', 'TQ very much for your effort üëç', 'Thanks', "Feature engineering /  Text representation - converting text to numbers 
Primitive ways : 
Label encoding ----> 1D matrix ( each word assigned a position(number) , final 1D matrix is created using those numbers only )
One Hot Encoding ----> 2D matrix ( size =  no. of words in statement x vocab size  , in a single row all elements are 0 , except that word's assigned number ) 
see 8:08


Disadvantage : 
1. Similar words do not have similar representation 
2. bigger size 
3. for undefined word no option available (OOV - out of vocabulary )
4. no fixed length .", '@codebasics Hello Sir i am a NLP intern. What else should i learn and improve to be the best .', "I'm unable to download the en_core_web_sm pipeline..!

['Check out our premium machine learning course with 2 Industry projects: https://codebasics.io/courses/machine-learning-for-data-science-beginners-to-advanced', 'Thank you very much, Its really a good explanationüëçüëçüëç', 'Data acquisition --> Acquiring piece of data from any source (e.g. internet etc.)
Text extraction and cleanup -->  Removing irrelevant information from the data acquired. (e.g. date ,author etc. removed)
Pre processing ----->
                                i) Sentence segmentation/tokenization --> dividing the whole data in small sentences on basis of full stop , commas etc. 
                                ii) Word tokenization ----> now , from the output of sentence segmentation , we will select some keywords 
                               iii) Stemming ---> Matching with base word but only removal of some alphabets from tokenized words ( e.g. -- eating - eat ( base word))
                               iv) Lemmatization  -->   Matching with base word which is completely different from base word , but we already mapped this ( e.g.---- ate -eat base word ))
Feature engineering ----> Conversion of pre-processed words to numbers ( by help of TF - IDF converter etc .)
Model building -----> we will build some models for training purpose ( naive bayes , random forest )
Evaluation --> match prediction score with truth score , again and again until non-diagonal elements of Confusion matrix becomes 0.(evaluate <---> pre-process)
Deployment -- to aws , azure etc.
Monitor and update ( again from starting i.e. data acquisition)
Make me correct , if any error present.', 'Video time 19.55

Mb someone can be intersted and this will be helpful, also i could made some mistakes, but i think someone will notice it)

NLP pipeline ‚Äì is a series of steps recurred to make a NLP application that transform raw text data into a desired output, such as a label, a summary, or a response. 
Label: In NLP, a label typically refers to a categorical or descriptive tag assigned to a piece of text or a dataset to categorize or classify it. Labels are often used in supervised machine learning tasks, such as text classification or sentiment analysis, where texts are assigned specific predefined categories or classes. For instance, in sentiment analysis, labels could be "positive," "negative," or "neutral," representing the sentiment conveyed in a text.
Summary: A summary in NLP refers to a condensed version of a longer text or document, capturing the main points, ideas, or key information while retaining the essence of the original content. Summarization tasks can be extractive (selecting and combining important sentences or phrases from the original text) or abstractive (generating new sentences that convey the main ideas).
Response: In an NLP context, a response is often used in dialogue systems or chatbots where the system generates or provides an answer or reply to a user query or input. The response is the output generated by the system based on its understanding of the input text or context. It could be a straightforward answer, an explanation, or any relevant information provided by the system.

First step in NLP pipeline is data Acquisition to get necessary data required to solve a NLP problem.
For data Acquisition u can use public data set or product interventions, or web scrapping, data augmentations, etc.

Second step is Extraction n Cleanups such as discard irrelevant information, creating simple version of ur text data, spell corrections, // removing

Third step is Preprocessing include
_sentence tokenization (NLT, spyCy)
_words tokenization
_Stemming ‚Äì reducing a word to it base exmp. loved, loves, loving ‚Äì love, no grammar
_Lemmatization ‚Äì reducing a word to it base WORD ate, eating ‚Äì eat
 
Fourth step is converting words into numbers Feature Engineering, here some techniques

N-grams: Creating features by considering sequences of words or characters together, known as n-grams (uni-grams for single words, bi-grams for pairs of words, tri-grams for triplets, etc.). This captures more contextual information.
Bag-of-Words (BoW): Representing text data as a vector of word counts or frequencies in a document. Each unique word in the vocabulary becomes a feature, and the count/frequency of each word becomes the feature value.
TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency): Similar to BoW, TF-IDF represents text data as numerical vectors, but it weighs the importance of words by considering their frequency in a specific document relative to their frequency in the entire corpus.

Fifth step Model Building with Machine learning (not always)
Model building in NLP refers to the process of constructing, training, and refining machine learning or deep learning models to perform specific natural language processing tasks. This process involves several key steps:
Model Selection: Choosing the appropriate architecture or model type that fits the specific NLP task. For instance, for text classification, models like Naive Bayes, Support Vector Machines (SVM), Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), or Transformer-based architectures might be considered.

Training: Utilizing the prepared dataset to train the selected model. During training, the model learns to understand the patterns and relationships within the data, adjusting its parameters to minimize the difference between predicted outputs and actual labels.

Hyperparameter Tuning: Adjusting model hyperparameters (learning rate, batch size, number of layers, etc.) to optimize the model's performance. This process often involves experimentation and validation on a separate dataset (validation set) to prevent overfitting.
Sixth step is Evaluation.
Evaluation in NLP refers to the process of assessing the performance, accuracy, and effectiveness of natural language processing models, algorithms, or systems. It involves measuring how well a particular NLP task or model accomplishes its intended objectives.

Evaluation in NLP can take several forms depending on the specific task being evaluated. Some common evaluation metrics and methodologies used in NLP include:

Accuracy: This metric measures the overall correctness of a model's predictions or classifications compared to the true labels or expected outputs.
Precision and Recall: These metrics are commonly used in tasks such as information retrieval, text classification, and named entity recognition. Precision measures the accuracy of positive predictions, while recall measures the ability of the model to find all the relevant instances in the data.
F1 Score: The F1 score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall and is often used in scenarios where both precision and recall are important and need to be balanced.
BLEU (Bilingual Evaluation Understudy): BLEU is a metric used to evaluate the quality of machine-translated text by comparing it to one or more human-generated reference translations.
ROUGE (Recall-Oriented Understudy for Gisting Evaluation): ROUGE is a set of metrics used for evaluating text summarization systems by comparing the generated summary to one or more reference summaries created by humans.
Perplexity: This metric is often used to evaluate language models by measuring how well a model predicts a sample of text. Lower perplexity values indicate better performance.
Human Evaluation: Sometimes, the most accurate evaluation involves human judgment. Human evaluators can assess the quality, coherence, and relevance of generated text, translations, or summaries.
Cross-Validation: It's a technique used to assess how well a model generalizes to new, unseen data by splitting the dataset into multiple subsets for training and evaluation.
Evaluation in NLP is crucial to understand how well a model performs on a given task, to compare different models or techniques, and to iteratively improve the performance of NLP systems. The choice of evaluation metric often depends on the specific NLP task and the goals of the project.

Seventh step is Deployment
When model is built, u can export it a file and deploy it on the cloud (Google, Azure, AWS, etc.) or write FastAPI based or Flask service around that model and deploy that service in the cloud. Also u can deploy to an end-to-end ML (Amazon SageMaker, Azure Machine Learning, H2O.a, databricks, etc.)
Eight step is Monitor n Update', 'Thanks so much!', 'I have studied for a whole semester to understand what you taught. Thank you']

from fastapi import FastAPI
import time
app=FastAPI()

@app.get("/hello/{num}")
async def hello(num):
    if int(num) < 50:
        
        def complex_computation(n):
            start_time = time.time()
            result = 0
            for i in range(n):
                result += i**2
            end_time = time.time()
            elapsed_time = end_time - start_time
            return result, elapsed_time
        result, elapsed_time = complex_computation(10**8)  # Complex computation for small num
        print(f"Result from if block: {result}")
        print(f"Time taken for if block: {elapsed_time:.2f} seconds")
    else:
        print("mango")
# Call the function with num that triggers the 'if' block', 'How can ƒ± use MINGW64 command prompt to write this command ?']

If the playlist is in below format it will be more useful.

Descriptive Statistics:

Mean, Median, Mode: Understanding central tendency.
Range, Variance, Standard Deviation: Measuring data dispersion.
Percentiles, Quartiles: Analyzing data distribution.

Inferential Statistics:

Hypothesis Testing: Formulating and testing hypotheses about population parameters based on sample data.
Confidence Intervals: Estimating the range within which a population parameter is likely to fall.
Significance Levels: Understanding and setting significance levels for hypothesis tests.

Probability Distributions:

Normal Distribution: Understanding and working with the normal distribution.
Binomial Distribution: Relevant for analyzing binary outcomes.
Poisson Distribution: Used for counting events over a fixed interval.

Correlation and Causation:
Correlation Coefficient: Measuring the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables.
Causation Awareness: Understanding that correlation does not imply causation.
Statistical Tests:
T-Tests: Comparing means of two groups.

Chi-Square Test: Analyzing associations between categorical variables.

ANOVA (Analysis of Variance): Comparing means of more than two groups.', 'god will bless you sir', 'Is there a way for French speakers to have a transcription and subtitles in French when purchasing one of your training courses?']

['Check out our premium machine learning course with 2 Industry projects: https://codebasics.io/courses/machine-learning-for-data-science-beginners-to-advanced', 'You are the best. So simple and down to earth', 'import cv2
from deepsort import DeepSort
from deepsort.detection import Detection

# Initialize DeepSORT tracker
deepsort = DeepSort("deepsort/resources/networks/mars-small128.pb", "cpu", max_cosine_distance=0.2, nn_budget=100)

# Initialize Haar cascades for object detection (you can replace this with a more robust detector like YOLO)
face_cascade = cv2.CascadeClassifier(cv2.data.haarcascades + 'haarcascade_frontalface_default.xml')

cap = cv2.VideoCapture('path_to_your_video.mp4') # Replace with your video file path

while True:
    ret, frame = cap.read()

    if not ret:
        break

    # Detect objects using Haar cascades (replace this with a more advanced detector if needed)
    faces = face_cascade.detectMultiScale(frame, scaleFactor=1.1, minNeighbors=5, minSize=(30, 30))

    detections = []
    for (x, y, w, h) in faces:
        detections.append(Detection([x, y, x+w, y+h], 1.0, [0, 0, 0], 1.0))

    trackers = deepsort.update(detections)

    for track in trackers:
        bbox = track.to_tlwh()
        cv2.rectangle(frame, (int(bbox[0]), int(bbox[1])), (int(bbox[2]), int(bbox[3])), (255, 255, 0), 2)
        cv2.putText(frame, f"ID: {track.track_id}", (int(bbox[0]), int(bbox[1])), cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX, 0.6, (0, 255, 0), 2)

    cv2.imshow('Tracking', frame)

    if cv2.waitKey(30) & 0xFF == 27: # Press 'Esc' to exit
        break

cap.release()
cv2.destroyAllWindows()', 'How to train an image classification model

So, those who want to volunteer or contribute can have one special group wherein 24/7 assistance and guidance can be provided. As nobody would be available in this hectic lifestyle, I guess volunteers/contributors can provide the assistance. This will create an environment of ease learning and solving any queries while working on. it. I hope It helps.', "In this current situation, students at schools and college are pushed to score marks and get jobs in some concern. But they have not been taught with the technical skills which the industry of current world demands. Only they have been taught what is what and that too the technologies they study in college syllabus is pretty much outdated. And they are lacking skills where to use and how to apply those technologies what they learnt in real world use cases.

So here comes my suggestion to discord community and code basics on it. Let us find and come with a most important and interesting use case of this world and come with solutions of it through various technologies.

Say suppose the use case is to address climate change problem and take it to people of different parts of the world on this,  skillsbasics use case is this. So web and app development team of skillsbasics complete course is to make an end to end app on this use case. Machine learning course of skillsbasics solve the same use case though their algorithms to make predictions on the same. So on whole what i mean is let us take an idea as a use case and implies various technologies on the same and give the real world use case as a package to the learner of the course. From learner's perspective, more than learning a technology, it will be like reading a story book, which will also walk him through the technologies as well encouraging him to think about helping the people of the world by addressing real world common problems of them.

And I strongly possess learning technologies will do nothing unless we apply it to solve the problem of common people through it. So i am suggesting this idea of *use case package*.", 'My suggestion is to reach this initiative successfully to all parts of India - multilingual country(at first, global reach is ultimate goal): Make a possibility to connect with the Contributors(Volunteer) of same mother tongue.
Though English is inevitable for Technology, this can makes higher  approachability(openness, easy & effective interaction).
In short, English-Public forum discussions, just add on Mother Tongue to understand the teaching in all levels.

As always, Thank you for your effort and support team !! ‚úåÔ∏èüëç']

def quicksort(arr):
    if len(arr) <= 1:
        return arr

    pivot = arr[len(arr) // 2]
    left = [x for x in arr if x < pivot]
    middle = [x for x in arr if x == pivot]
    right = [x for x in arr if x > pivot]

    return quicksort(left) + middle + quicksort(right)', '‚ù§', 'you are always a better explainer than others on the you tube ‚ù§‚úå']

['Do you want to learn technology from me? Check https://codebasics.io/ for my affordable video courses.', 'Compact code does not always mean it is more readable', 'Really good vedio on code review', '"Write compact code" (1:10)
This is questionable advice. We should write code that meets functional/non-functional requirements but is easy to read. Do you want to spend 2 minutes trying to understand 1 line of code or 15 seconds understanding 5 lines of code?  (This is actually discussed later in the video). 

"phone_info is not used in multiple places" (2:55)
Correct, but it **is** used when stepping through code (which is generally a good idea). You can't see what's in phone_info if you return it directly. For the sake of one temporary variable you make debugging easier without having to re-write the code. 

The other advice is great!', 'wow, great to see more videos like this.', 'This was pretty good info', 'Excellent job. Thanks for the upload, it really helps.', 'This guy is literally taught me much more than my professors.. Thanks a lot', 'Nice video, more or less this is written in the wonderful Clean Code (by Robert Martin). But sometimes I prefer to store the output of a function on a variable just for debugging purposes, or to store something on a temporary variable to avoid train wagons (i.e. multiple rows with getA().getB().get(C).setXXX(), I prefer to declare C c = getA().getB())', '10:03 you can do nothing in java without class and object']

['Do you want to learn python from me with a lot of interactive quizzes, and exercises? Here is my project-based python learning course: https://codebasics.io/courses/python-for-beginner-and-intermediate-learners', 'Wow I learnt so much from this video thankssüòáüòáüòá', 'Some additional functionaity of frozenlists for anyine reading this:
Frozensets are hashable. Sets are not.

What that means is that frozensets can be used as keys in a dictionary:
You can use frozenset({1, 2, 3}) or frozenset({"apple", "mango"}) as a key in a dictionary.
You cannot use set({1, 2, 3}) or set({"apple", "mango"}) as a key in a dictionary.

This is useful if you ever want to use a list of elements as a key in a dictionary. Convert that list to a frozenset and use it as a key.', 'So nice and clear explanation :)', 'Wow, fantastic video, thank you so much!! The examples at the end were so clear. def calculate_area(base, height, shape='triangle'):
    if shape == 'triangle':
        area = 0.5*base*height
        return area
    elif shape == 'rectangle':
        area_r = base *height
        return area_r
    else:
        return area
